"Ptya, you're a stupid!" said Natdsha. 
"Not more stupid than you, madam," said the nine-year-old Ptya, with the air of an old brigadier. 
The countess had been prepared by Anna Mikhdylovna's hints at dinner. On retiring to her own room, she sat in an armchair, her eyes fixed on a miniature portrait of her son on the lid of a snuffbox, while the tears kept coming into her eyes. Anna Mikhdylovna, with the let-
